Better Breed Cameroun propose de nombreu:
Better Breed Cameroon offers numerous services and activities aimed at empowering and mobilizing young people across the country. These initiatives include:
- Training and mentoring programs (Fellowship): The Better Breed Cameroon Legacy fellowship is a six-month training program covering non-profit management, positive youth development, research for advocacy, strategic communication, financial management, as well as monitoring and evaluation. Participants learn practical skills and receive mentoring to effectively lead and support nonprofit organizations.
- Youth Employability Bootcap (YEB): This program aims to develop the professional skills of young Cameroonians who have not managed to find a job after obtaining their diploma. It includes skills development workshops and mentoring to prepare participants for the workforce.
- Community engagement initiatives: events like the Reading Caravan, which promotes literacy and civic engagement among youth through interactive reading sessions and discussions. These events take place in different cities, including Bamenda and Yaoundé.
- Sama Randy Youth Writing Competition: An annual competition inviting all young Cameroonian undergraduate students to submit contributions on pressing societal issues. This competition promotes literacy, civic engagement and leadership development among young people.
- Creative workshops: organization of jewelry and slipper making workshops, with locally produced Cameroonian materials. These workshops aim to equip young participants with practical and entrepreneurial skills, while promoting creativity and pride in their Cameroonian identity.
- Advocacy and awareness campaigns: Through various programs and initiatives, Better Breed Cameroon raises awareness of issues affecting young people and advocates for positive change. This includes promoting good citizenship and encouraging active participation in community development.
- Youth of the Month Program: rewards young leaders who contribute significantly to their community. These young people are presented as inspiring examples for other young people.

via l'incubateur: la structure accompagn:
via the incubator: the structure supports the entrepreneur, whatever his stage of development, from the idea that is being built to the company that wants to change scale. Via the professional training center, Boukarou supports learners in capacity building on entrepreneurial soft skills, and on specific professional skills as needed, these training courses are awarded by a certificate or certificate recognized by the Ministry of Vocational Training. Via Bosangi sarl, the structure supports entrepreneurs in the distribution of Made In Cameroon products and services, in particular with a partnership built with a chain of 180 stores throughout Cameroon. From January 2026, in partnership with a category 2 Microfinance company, Boukaseed Sarl will be able to support the search for financing solutions.
Boukarou also has a coworking space in Maroua and another at its headquarters in Douala in which it hosts artist workshops, or filming of films, series, video clips by many Cameroonian urban music artists.

LUKMEF accompagne les jeunes, filles et: LUKMEF supports young people, girls and boys, through transformative programs that strengthen their skills, confidence and opportunities. l'espace met en œuvre des activités pour: the space implements activities for a mainly young and urban target, but older audiences are also welcome. Monitoring by age group is not yet carried out very well but on a program such as Womendia for Art carried out in 2024, discussions on gender-based violence were carried out with a population of 965 people, 80% of whom were young people aged 17 to 25. The space estimates reaching around 200 to 300 young people per week through the activities on its site. The Womendia for Art program, focused on training, awareness-raising and performances, has enabled many women to break the silence on GBV, to better master their rights, to express themselves on the issues that concern them and to bring men and young boys to lead the fight with them.

- Limited access to financing to support startups and innovative projects.

Depuis sa création, Better Breed Camerou: Since its creation, Better Breed Cameroon has been self-financed by its founders, with the support of patrons and supporters. Therefore, lack of funding and resources remains the main challenge, limiting the organization's ability to scale up its programs. Distance and geographic barriers also make it difficult to expand activities to remote or underserved areas, depriving many vulnerable youth of access to mentoring, training and civic engagement. The reluctance of young people to get involved and the lack of self-confidence that they can demonstrate constitutes the third challenge that the organization must face.

- Logistical difficulties for the full participation of certain young people in activities (transport, accommodation)
- High cost of internet access
- Cost of maintaining a dedicated center facilitator
- Lack of long-term financing
- Weak links with other non-financial resource networks such as other youth spaces
- Avoir plus de moyens matériels et de r:
- Have more material means and human resources to be able to have a greater volume of work. 
- Have the capacity to protect the result already achieved, by supporting young people trained in the start-up or development of their activities because the business world and more broadly society are spaces of incredible violence in countries like Cameroon.

Le Boukarou a été fondé par deux personn: Boukarou was founded by two people: Arsene Kapnang, who is today on the optional guidance council and Jean Patrick Ketcha, who is the operational actor who brings the ecosystem to life with his half dozen collaborators
Tanyi Christian E. est cofondateur et di: Tanyi Christian E. is co-founder and CEO of LUKMEF (Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Foundation). Coming from an impoverished rural community, he financed his education himself and studied mathematics, computer science and chemistry at the University of Buea. He holds a certificate in conflict analysis from the American Institute of Peace. Before LUKMEF, he worked as an IT consultant and developed open source tools such as “Smart Budget” and “Pharmacy Plus”. As an educator, peace activist and community organizer, he has over a decade of development experience in Cameroon. Internationally, he has presented at global forums and UN venues on peace, governance and youth empowerment. Christian is generally considered a major motivator and advocate for collective action. Christian is now a member of the HCT and co-chair of the localization working group for Cameroon.
Fondateur et directeur: M. Ebong Lovert: Founder and Director: Mr. Ebong Lovert Ewang, is an educationist, researcher, professional disaster risk manager and youth leader with a passion for service and development of youth and communities.Holding a bachelor's degree in accounting, Lover is currently completing a professional master's degree in disaster risk management at the University of Buea, Cameroon. Lovert has over 7 years of experience in the humanitarian and development ecosystem, holding varied positions in finance, projects, operations and rapid field support. He has worked for several national and international NGOs in Cameroon, such as the Danish Refugee Council, Care International, SpringAid International Development, African Millennium Development Network (AFRINET), Core Care Africa, etc. He has also actively participated in numerous social and community peacebuilding initiatives, including Friedrich Ebert, the National Fund for Democracy, Swiss Peace, Local Youth Corner and Reach Cameroon. Lovert is a certified trainer and facilitator in education in emergencies (ESU) by UNESCO as part of the multi-year program “Education without delay” for Cameroon. Lovert is also supported by a group of other very experienced and dedicated young people like Dr. Jean Baptiste Fonkam Fonkam, Chelsea Kunbid Pasiah (PhD student), Njumbe Desire (very experienced sociologist), Anna Nkumbe (MSc.) Alegeju Besua (ERAMUS scholar).

Ludovic Champleins Ngahenou (33 ans) est: Ludovic Champleins Ngahenou (33 years old) is a Cameroonian dancer, choreographer and cultural entrepreneur. Ludovic Ngahenou lost his parents very early in a car accident, he discovered a passion for art and culture as head of cultural activities in 3rd grade until 12th grade. In 2007, faced with numerous family pressures, Cnampleins Ngahenou was kicked out by one of his host families, and became what is commonly called in Cameroon Nanga Mboko (street child). He then dances to survive in the streets that are now his home, with a penchant for the country's heritage dances. Holder of a Master's degree in Law and Public Administration, but also in business management and human resources, he launched into the associative movement and cultural entrepreneurship in order to contribute to the career development of dancers in Cameroon and around the world. In 2011, Champleins launched the Patrie Art project, which was voted best cultural entrepreneurship project in the Entrepreneur for Tomorrow competition. In 2019 he stayed in the cities of Bamako in Mali and Dakar in Senegal for activities concerning the evolution of the Patrie Art project. It was upon his return from this trip that he prepared the formal registration of his space which obtained legalization in March 2020.
Better Breed Cameroon a été co-fondée pa:
Better Breed Cameroon was co-founded by Dr Monique Kwachou, a Cameroonian writer, experienced researcher on education, gender and development issues with over a decade of academic and practical experience gained working with diverse employers, from higher education institutions to civil society organizations and international development agencies. She is currently a Research Associate at the University of Bristol and Chair of the Board of Better Breed Cameroon. The other co-founders are:
- Dr. Etta Mercy Aki, an emblematic figure in education, affiliated with the University of Buea in Cameroon, where she is a lecturer and vice-dean for studies and student affairs. With a strong background in research methods and innovative program design, Dr. Etta has delivered impactful workshops that stimulate student aspirations and stimulate critical thinking. She also serves as a technical advisor for youth engagement initiatives, which bridge the gap between education and real-world applications.
- Dr. Kemngong Atemnkeng, education researcher at the National Education Center of the Ministry of Scientific Research and Innovation. She is also head of the Office for the valorization and popularization of research results for the South-West region, in Cameroon.
- Dr. Yiefon Annabel (researcher at the University of Dschang) and Ms. Mariline Mbua Make. Both have experience in project management and finance for nonprofit organizations.

Better Breed Cameroon a été créée en 201:
Better Breed Cameroon was established in 2013 with the aim of building the capacity of young Cameroonians and empowering them by providing them with the knowledge to take up leadership positions. Better Breed Cameroon was co-founded by Dr Monique Kwachou, a Cameroonian writer, experienced researcher on education, gender and development issues with over a decade of academic and practical experience gained working with diverse employers, from higher education institutions to civil society organizations and international development agencies. She is currently a Research Associate at the University of Bristol and Chair of the Board of Better Breed Cameroon. The other co-founders are:
- Dr. Etta Mercy Aki, an emblematic figure in education, affiliated with the University of Buea in Cameroon, where she is a lecturer and vice-dean for studies and student affairs. With a strong background in research methods and innovative program design, Dr. Etta has delivered impactful workshops that stimulate student aspirations and stimulate critical thinking. She also serves as a technical advisor for youth engagement initiatives, which bridge the gap between education and real-world applications.
- Dr. Kemngong Atemnkeng, education researcher at the National Education Center of the Ministry of Scientific Research and Innovation. She is also head of the Office for the valorization and popularization of research results for the South-West region, in Cameroon.
- Dr. Yiefon Annabel (researcher at the University of Dschang) and Ms. Mariline Mbua Make. Both have experience in project management and finance for nonprofit organizations.
Better Breed Cameroon étant né avec la v: Better Breed Cameroon, having been born with the desire not to lock itself into dependence on international subsidies, was built by favoring local partnerships with structures sharing the same values ​​or capable of providing logistical support in the implementation of its activities. the organization does not have any experience of collaboration with cooperation organizations such as Expertise France.
Better Breed mène ses activités en ligne: Better Breed carries out its activities online and in person, making them accessible to young people. Given their limited resources, they have not put in place specific infrastructure for accessibility for young people with disabilities.

L'organisation a une expérience de mise: The organization has experience implementing support programs with a strong social impact for young people in situations of socio-economic vulnerability.
Better Breed Cameroon est une associatio: Better Breed Cameroon is an association which is mainly financed by the contributions of its founders with the support of patrons and supporters as well as the sale of fashion articles via the Memorabilia project.
Oui elle organise essentiellement des pr: Yes, it mainly organizes programs related to youth leadership and entrepreneurship. All of Better Breed Cameroon's activities aim to train a generation of informed, competent and committed young leaders, determined to contribute positively within their community and within the nation as a whole.
Le budget annuel à fin 2024 était de 30: The annual budget at the end of 2024 was 30 million FCFA.

En 12 ans d'activités l'association esti: In 12 years of activities, the association estimates that it has reached a total of 8 of the 10 regions of the country.

L'organisation est dirigée par un consei: The organization is governed by a board of directors made up of five women, who are co-founders of Better Breed. The executive team is led by Chi Margaret, a young woman of 25 years old, accompanied by an operations director also aged 25 and a communications manager. So 100% of leadership is female.
Better Breed Camerooon accueillent des g: Better Breed Camerooon welcomes groups of 5 to 10 young people in its training or support activities. The fellowship program, for example, made it possible to support 4 young talents for 6 months in 2024. Likewise, the training on creating artisanal jewelry in August 2025 welcomed 5 young women over 3 days. In 12 years of activity, Better Breed estimates that it has impacted nearly 3.5 million young Cameroonians. A portion of these young people impacted are, however, below the 18-30 age range since the program to promote engagement and reading (Readinig Caravan) takes place in schools, colleges and high schools.
L'organisation est excusivement gérée pa: The organization is exclusively run by young people. The executive team and volunteers are all under 30 years old. The main founder and the other members who recently crossed the threshold of 30 have decided to leave the operational management of the association to the youngest and to support them via the Board of Directors. The interview with one of the winners of the Better Breed Cameroon Fellowship program highlighted the great satisfaction of the beneficiaries with the support provided to them by the organization.
Oui Better Breed a un programme spécifiq: Yes Better Breed has a specific program on youth leadership; the Better Breed Cameroon Fellowship which also made it possible to detect the 2 new leaders of the organization. This program is a 6-month immersion combining training, mentoring and networking opportunities for the winners. The six-month training program covers nonprofit management, positive youth development, research for advocacy, strategic communication, financial management, and monitoring and evaluation. Participants learn practical skills and receive mentoring to effectively lead and support nonprofit organizations.

Malgré l'absence de partenariat internat: Despite the absence of international partnerships, Better Breed has been able to build an economic model which has allowed it, in 12 years of activity, to achieve a total annual income amounting to 30 million FCFA.

An activity has been set up to support them in this research (Youth Employability Bootcamp). The organization also takes great care to remain inclusive of language by producing content in both national languages ​​(French and English). For the literary competition that it organizes each year, it ensures that there are as many winners who have written in English as in French.

Patrie'Art est une association qui se fi:
Patrie'Art is an association which finances itself through different channels with an ambition to detach itself as much as possible from the support of donors: 
- Generation of income via annual festivals (e.g. La Nuit du Patrimoine, Bâtir le Commun)
- Cultural services offered to businesses and individuals, with commission charged for space management

L’association travaille activement avec:
The association actively works with young people with disabilities, juvenile delinquency and from disadvantaged neighborhoods. Artistic training is designed to promote the social and cultural integration of vulnerable young people. The beneficiary we interviewed is also a young dancer on a wheelchair. Inclusion at Patrie’Art is:
• Young people from disadvantaged neighborhoods or in complex family situations: around 200 young people supported in support, training and artistic expression activities.
• Young people from street associations supported by the program: around 200 beneficiaries.
• People living with disabilities (Yaoundé and Douala): nearly 100 beneficiaries, through inclusive activities and adapted workshops.
La formation au leadership constitue l’u:
Leadership training constitutes one of the major areas of support for PATRIE ART. It materializes through:
• Capacity building workshops focused on speaking out, self-confidence and management of community projects.
• Mentoring sessions supervised by arts, culture and personal development professionals.
• Practical programs integrating artistic creation as a social leadership tool, allowing young people to become agents of change within their communities.

These training courses aim to stimulate the autonomy, creativity and civic engagement of young people and women supported by the organization.
Patrie'Art mène principalement ses activ: Patrie'Art mainly carries out its activities in the city of Douala where its headquarters are located. Certain activities are taken outside this city from time to time, particularly during the holidays, to meet young people in smaller towns.
Le budget annuel moyen de PATRIE ART au: The average annual budget of PATRIE ART in Cameroon is estimated at 10,000,000 FCFA. This budget covers training, awareness, artistic creation and community projects carried out throughout the year.

l'équipe opérationnelle est composé des: the operational team is made up of 6 members of the executive office supplemented by 5 other employees who mainly work on training. All 11 ensure the implementation of the projects.
Le projet le plus ambitieux mené par PAT: The most ambitious project carried out by PATRIE ART in Cameroon is “WOMENDIA”, a program to combat sexual and gender-based violence against women. This project, lasting one year, benefited from funding of 15,000,000 FCFA from the French Embassy in Cameroon, supplemented by 7,000,000 FCFA from other partners, for a total budget of 22,000,000 FCFA. The program was deployed between Douala and Yaoundé, with a considerable impact: more than 8,000 people made aware, not counting the direct beneficiaries supported psychologically and materially following the program. The structure has therefore already received funding equal to the envelope provided by EF. The association is currently working on a new project “Building the Common”, which will be a program of exchange and intercultural creation between France, Germany and Cameroon with an overall budget of between 30,000 and 50,000 euros.

Patrie'Art a été fondé en 2011, par Ludo: Patrie'Art was founded in 2011, by Ludovic Champleins Ngahenou (33 years old) a Cameroonian dancer, choreographer and cultural entrepreneur. Champleins Ngahenou lost his parents very early in a car accident, he discovered a passion for art and culture as head of cultural activities in 3rd grade until 12th grade. In 2007, faced with numerous family pressures, Champleins Ngahenou was kicked out by one of his host families, and became what is commonly called in Cameroon Nanga Mboko (street child). He then dances to survive in the streets that are now his home, with a penchant for the country's heritage dances. Holder of a Master's degree in Law and Public Administration, but also in business management and human resources, he launched into the associative movement and cultural entrepreneurship in order to contribute to the career development of dancers in Cameroon and around the world. In 2011, Champleins launched the Patrie'Art project which was voted best cultural entrepreneurship project in the Entrepreneur for Tomorrow competition. In 2019 he stayed in the cities of Bamako in Mali and Dakar in Senegal for activities concerning the evolution of the Patrie'Art project. It was upon his return from this trip that he prepared the formal registration of his space which obtained legalization in March 2020.

Le Boukarou a commencé à se structurer e:
Boukarou began to structure itself in 2018 by first creating an incubator, then in 2019 by creating a professional training center which obtained its ministerial approval in 2023. Boukarou was founded by two people: Arsene Kapnang, who is today on the optional guidance council and Jean Patrick Ketcha, who is the operational actor who brings the ecosystem to life with his half dozen employees. 
Jean-Patrick Ketcha graduated from Paris Nanterre University where he obtained a master's degree in law in 2006. He also holds a master's degree in international business and commerce obtained from OMNES Education in France. After starting his professional career in 2010 as a sales manager at the Industrial Concrete Company of Cameroon, then in the real estate company Millenuim, he created Boukarou, a structure dedicated to supporting young entrepreneurs and women. JP Ketcha is a seasoned founder with extensive experience in the civic and social organization sector. He is also a talented negotiator, business planner, sales manager and speaker. He is also a member of the Board of Directors of Afric'innov and a member of the AUF Strategic Orientation Council. 
Arsène Kapnang graduated from the Multinational School of Telecommunications in Dakar. A year after obtaining his professional license in IT & telecommunications, he became Project Manager at Hi-TECH MEDIA, where he almost plays the role of technical director of this structure. He began his relationship with the world of support when he became a Brand Communicator at Eduair, a platform that offers quality educational content via digital with or without an internet connection. In 2017, he was spotted by Studely, the first French financial service dedicated to supporting students on international mobility, and became its marketing & communications manager. After demonstrating within the group that he can be counted on to improve things, he was appointed Country Manager in 2018 of the Cameroonian subsidiary to facilitate the integration of students in foreign countries. He created Boukarou in parallel with JP Ketcha.
L'entretien avec l'un des bénéficiaires: The interview with one of the Boukarou beneficiaries revealed great satisfaction both for the content of the support that was provided on leadership and entrepreneurship and for the opportunities that were created for this young entrepreneur living in the city of Maroua. The association's office is made up of 3 people who are all over 30 years old (43 years old for President JP Ketcha). Next to this office is an operational team of 7 people including 2 people under 30 years old. Boukarou has chosen to gradually involve young people in view of the responsibilities that it considers too important.
Le Boukarou dispose d'un espace de cowor: Boukarou has a coworking space in Maroua equipped with 3 rooms for a total capacity of 70 people. At the headquarters in Douala, private offices can accommodate up to 10 companies, and coworking 80 people. The outdoor space also makes it possible to host artist workshops, or filming of films, series, video clips by many Cameroonian urban music artists. The coworking spaces have a few screens, desktop computers and video projectors. In the town of Edea in which it recently started activities, there is not yet its own establishment. The activities are deployed directly on the IUT campus.

Le Boukarou a fait le choix depuis 2018: Since 2018, Boukarou has chosen to create different legal structures to adapt to the ecosystem. Today it has several legal structures for its operations, a SARL (Le Boukarou SARL) and an Association (Le Boukarou 237) to carry out the main activities of the incubator and the training center. Another company, Bosangi Sarl, was created to support entrepreneurs in the distribution of their products and services (Market Access theme), and finally the Boukaseeds advisory structure was created to support them in their search for financing. The structure is financed by revenue from its B2B and B2C services. the Hub is financed by the sale of B2B and B2C services (training, incubation, distribution), combined with technical and financial partnerships.
Pas d'infrastructure particulière pour l: No special infrastructure for welcoming disabled people.
Le Boukarou accompagne des cohorte d'une: Boukarou supports cohorts of around ten young people or less as for its Boukamp Maroua 2025 program which put 10 young people bringing solutions into competition for the Far North region. For these training activities, however, it collaborates with universities in which it trains entire classes. At the IUT of Douala for example (which covers the city of Douala and that of Edea) it trains all 1st, 2nd and 3rd year students in leadership, entrepreneurship and Innovation, i.e. several hundred students who will be supported on their campus.

YESI Rwanda is a youth organisation that: YESI Rwanda is a youth organization that promotes social innovation and entrepreneurship among young people across the country (Rwanda), operating from Kigali. It provides leadership training, incubation support, and project funding opportunities for youth from diverse regions. Working closely with community‑based youth groups and development partners, YESI Rwanda faces challenges in access to technical resources. The organization continues to play a key role in empowering young Rwandans to become innovative problem-solvers.
Acts of Gratitude, created in 2011 and b: Acts of Gratitude, created in 2011 and based in Kigali, is a youth‑focused NGO promoting social entrepreneurship and innovation. The organization supports young changemakers through workshops, incubation, and mentorship programs that help turn ideas into sustainable ventures across Rwanda (including youth from both urban and rural districts). AOG collaborates with local youth networks and development partners and is funded through donations and partnerships. Key challenges include funding sustainability and resource mobilization. AOG stands out for its innovative approach to equipping youth with entrepreneurial and leadership skills.
Akazi Kanoze Access is a professional tr: Akazi Kanoze Access is a professional training and employment-facilitation organization established in 2009 in Kigali. Its programs aim to equip young people with life and work‑readiness skills that enhance employability. Operating nationally (in more than 20 districts including Huye, Gisagara, Nyanza, Nyaruguru, Ruhango, Nyamasheke, Karongi, Rusizi, Rutsiro, Rwamagana, Musanze, Gakenke, Nyabihu, Muhanga, Kayonza, Nyagatare and Kigali itself. It collaborates with private‑sector actors, NGOs, and training centers. Funded mainly through donor supports. It remains a cornerstone institution in promoting youth employability and workforce development in Rwanda.
Established in 2012, iDebate Rwanda is a: Established in 2012, iDebate Rwanda is a youth‐focused NGO that promotes civil discourse and critical thinking through debate programs across schools and youth spaces throughout Rwanda (including in Kigali and other provinces). Based in Kigali, it operates country‑wide and collaborates with schools, youth clubs, and sponsors. The organization’s work builds youth confidence, communication, and leadership capacities. Funded by grants and sponsorships, iDebate faces challenges in scaling its impact and strengthening institutional capacity. It continues to be a dynamic platform fostering civic engagement and informed public dialogue.
Founded in 2013 by unemployed university: Founded in 2013 by unemployed university graduates in Rubavu, EPO is a registered non‑profit (certificate No342/RGB/NGO/LP/07/2018) that empowers youth, women and children across Rwanda. Through partnerships with donors and public institutions, EPO has built a national reputation for youth and women empowerment. Despite this strong trajectory, EPO continues to wrestle with sustaining its long-term programs and scaling its reach beyond key districts. It remains a proactive agent in transforming unemployed graduates into entrepreneurs and change-makers.
Peace and Love Proclaimers is a youth‑le: Peace and Love Proclaimers is a youth‑led organization that operates primarily within high schools in Rwanda. Through grassroots initiatives, PLP empowers young people globally (and in Rwanda) to take responsibility for social, economic and cultural development in their communities. Its vision is a unified world free from divisionism, and its mission is establishing positive change in youth through initiatives such as reconciliation events and youth empowerment. With over 73 high school chapters and 10,000+ members since 2007, PLP draws on school‑based mobilization and youth leadership. Despite its broad network, the organization faces challenges in securing deep integration into post-school youth pathways, and maintaining consistent funding for its expansion. It remains a pioneer in youth‑driven peace and reconciliation work.
OFYER is a youth-focused NGO dedicated t: OFYER is a youth-focused NGO dedicated to empowering young people in Rwanda through leadership development, skills training, and civic engagement initiatives. Headquartered in Kigali, the organization works in multiple districts across Rwanda to provide mentorship, educational support, and opportunities for youth participation in community development. OFYER collaborates with local communities, schools, and development partners, and is primarily funded through grants and partnerships. Challenges include expanding outreach to rural areas and ensuring sustainable funding, but the organization continues to strengthen youth capacity nationwide.
Commentaires : Rwanda’s administrative a: Comments: Rwanda’s administrative and geographic configuration is notably distinct compared to many other African countries. The country is divided into only five regions—Kigali, Eastern, Western, Northern, and Southern—covering a relatively compact territory of approximately 26,000km². This small size and limited number of regions, combined with a well‑decentralized and organized government leadership system, allow NGOs to operate efficiently and implement programs nationwide without the logistical complexities faced in larger African countries. All NGOs must be officially registered with the Rwanda Governance Board (RGB), ensuring oversight, coordination, and compliance with national standards. As a result, interventions can reach a broader population more quickly, facilitate close collaboration with local authorities, and allow for more consistent monitoring and evaluation. This geographic compactness and strong governance enable NGOs to scale initiatives, harmonize efforts, and achieve impact at a national level more rapidly than in countries with larger territories and more fragmented administrative divisions.
AFRIYAN Rwanda is part of a regional you: AFRIYAN Rwanda is part of a regional youth network committed to advancing youth development, advocacy, and social inclusion across Rwanda (including youth from multiple provinces) from its base in Kigali. The organization supports initiatives related to health, gender equality, and youth empowerment. Working in partnership with government agencies and development partners, AFRIYAN provides a platform for youth participation in policy-processes. Our Past Initiative is a Rwanda‑based NG: Our Past Initiative is a Rwanda‑based NGO whose work focuses on youth mobilization, peace building and social solidarity through commemoration and remembrance of the 1994 genocide, as well as support to vulnerable communities. Over the past 12+ years, the organization has organized commemoration events bringing youth and older generations together, and supported initiatives like home renovations for survivors, health insurance facilitation, and youth entrepreneurship support. It promotes youth interaction through cultural activities, leadership workshops and positive citizenship. While it holds a distinct niche in peace building and social cohesion, its challenge lies in diversifying funding. It remains a key bridge between Rwanda’s past and its youth-driven future.
Formed in 2019, Talent Match is a Rwanda: Formed in 2019, Talent Match is a Rwandan‑based social enterprise dedicated to tackling youth unemployment by offering students and recent graduates skills training, mentorship, job and internship placements. By partnering with higher learning institutions, Talent Match seeks to mold a capable, agile and dynamic workforce for Rwanda’s future.  Despite its commendable growth and regional ambitions, Talent Match needs the right financial and technical support to deepen its reach and widen its impact. It stands out as an impactful bridge between education and employment for youth.
Empower Rwanda is a women‑led NGO establ: Empower Rwanda is a women‑led NGO established in 2019 (registered under Legal Personality N°696/RGB/NGO/LP/11/2020) in Kigali. Its mission is to empower vulnerable children, youth and women via access to quality education and health, socio-economic empowerment and advocacy interventions. The organization currently supports over 400 teenage mothers in three districts (Rwamagana, Gatsibo and Nyagatare in Eastern Province). While its impact is clear in advancing girls’ and women’s rights, Empower Rwanda grapples with ensuring funding sustainability, expanding district-level reach and scaling its programs in a way that sustains long-term institutional capacity. Empower Rwanda continues to lead in empowering young women as agents of change.
Hanga Hub serves as a national centre fo: Hanga Hub serves as a national center for innovation and entrepreneurship based in Kigali and beyond, offering youth‑focused programs in digital skills, incubation, and mentorship. It is backed by partnerships with public institutions and the private sector. Hanga hub hosts its activities in well built location, wih laptops, desktops and rooms available to host the workshops. It remains a flagship initiative promoting youth‑led innovation and creative‑industry development in Rwanda.
UWEZO is a youth‑led disabled persons or: UWEZO is a youth‑led disabled persons organization in Rwanda, run by and for young people with disabilities. he organization partners with local and international institutions such as DOT Rwanda, AbleChildAfrica, and the National Council for Persons with Disabilities to deliver inclusive entrepreneurship training, educational support, internship opportunities and assistive‑technology interventions for youth and children with disabilities. UWEZO has distinguished itself in shaping the narrative around youth disability inclusion. However, it faces ongoing challenges around resource mobilization, infrastructural accommodations and integrating its youth‑with‑disabilities constituency into mainstream employment. Akazi Kanoze Access is a professional tr: Akazi Kanoze Access is a professional training and employment-facilitation organization established in 2009 in Kigali. Its programs aim to equip young people with life and work‑readiness skills that enhance employability. Operating nationally (in more than 20 districts including Huye, Gisagara, Nyanza, Nyaruguru, Ruhango, Nyamasheke, Karongi, Rusizi, Rutsiro, Rwamagana, Musanze, Gakenke, Nyabihu, Muhanga, Kayonza, Nyagatare and Kigali itself. Strengths : \n•\tGovernance & leadership:
Strengths: 
• Governance & leadership: Clear governance, strong youth-led leadership, and a proven participatory culture where alumni become trainers and mentors.
• Operational capacity: Efficient delivery model with strong coordination, established debate clubs across schools, and experience managing large youth cohorts
• Sectoral relevance: Deep expertise in debate, critical thinking, public speaking, and civic education—fully aligned with NewLeaderLab’s civic leadership objectives.
• Networks & reach: Strong relationships with schools, teachers, coaches, and educational institutions.
• Inclusion: High participation of young women (70% in debate programs); strong access to low-income, public schools, and rural youth
• Pedagogical strength: Well-developed curricula, debate modules, and training systems.
• key Programming: Debate & Public Education, Teachers Program, Youth Leadership and Volunterism, Youth Exchange Program
Weaknesses: 
• Financial vulnerability: High dependency on donor grants; limited revenue-generating activities.
• M&E limitations: Lack of EU-standardized indicators, limited alumni tracking, 
• Disability inclusion: Program accessibility for visually/hearing-impaired youth is still limited.
Points of Attention (Aligned with AEYA/NewLeaderLab Standards)
• Strengthen EU-compliant M&E systems
• Align financial and procurement systems with EU compliance standards
Strengths\n•\tSectoral specialization: S:
Strengths
• Sectoral specialization: Strong focus on youth employability, entrepreneurship, job readiness, and soft-skills training.
• Pedagogical approach: Structured leadership and employability curricula, digital tools, mentorship, and career coaching.
• Youth engagement: High levels of co-creation and peer leadership. 
• Inclusivity: Female participation consistently above 50%.
• Geographical reach: Hybrid delivery (online + in districts), allowing outreach to rural and peri-urban youth.
• Strong Programming: Employability Program, The Entrepreneurship Program, University Career Development Strengthening Project
Weaknesses
• Financial capacity: Modest budget (~€35,000); limited diversified income streams. 
• Institutional documentation: SOPs and donor-compliant policies need reinforcing.
• M&E: Employment tracking and long-term leadership outcomes need structured systems.
Points of Attention & Recommendations (Aligned with AEYA/NLL Standards).
• Institutional strengthening (high priority): Develop monitoring and evaluation systems aligned with AEYA standards, and reinforce procurement and reporting procedures to meet EU compliance requirements. 
• For the initial phase, consider co-implementing the New Leaders Lab with a more mature NGO (such as Resonate or iDebate) to help manage administrative responsibilities while benefiting from their established thematic expertise.

Strengths\n•\tOrganizational capacity: H:
Strengths
• Organizational capacity: High budget (~€500,000), strong administrative systems, hybrid virtual/physical delivery. 
• Sectoral expertise: Leading organization in women’s empowerment, storytelling, confidence building, personal leadership.
• Pedagogical excellence: High-quality workshop modules, skilled facilitators, strong participant satisfaction.
• Gender inclusion: Reaches 80% female participants; strong empowerment focus.

• Donor credibility: Long-standing partnerships with international agencies.

Weaknesses
• Target group concentration: Primarily focused on women; less experience with mixed-gender cohorts.
• Disability inclusion: Needs stronger systems and adaptations.
Points of Attention (Aligned with AEYA/NLL Standards)
- Adapt content for New leader Lab inclusivity requirement: Develop modules suitable for boys, mixed cohorts, and vulnerable groups beyond women.

Weaknesses

Talent Match demonstrates strong potenti:
Talent Match demonstrates strong potential and institutional readiness to implement the New Leaders Lab, particularly in the areas of youth employability, leadership, and entrepreneurship development. Founded in 2019 as a social enterprise, the organization operates with an annual budget of approximately €35,000 and reaches more than 50,000 young people—primarily job seekers and recent graduates navigating a highly competitive labor market. Its hybrid funding model (grants and partnerships) and clear focus on capacity-building make it a credible and agile implementing partner for the Lab.
1. The organization’s programs are designed to bridge the gap between education and employment through practical skills training, mentorship, and entrepreneurship support. By combining career guidance, leadership development, and digital learning, Talent Match provides relevant and results-oriented services that directly align with the objectives of the New Leaders Lab. Its programs are built on participatory learning approaches, encouraging youth co-creation, mentorship, and peer leadership—key elements for fostering ownership and sustainability.
2. Gender and inclusion are well-integrated across programs. Female participation regularly meets or exceeds 50%, particularly in mentorship and employability tracks. The organization ensures safe, inclusive environments accessible to youth from both urban and rural settings being present on university campuses both in Kigali and upcountry. While inclusion measures for young people with disabilities are still developing, a culture of openness and respect is well established.
3. Talent Match also maintains a diverse geographical reach, delivering activities across Kigali and peripheral districts, with growing digital access that enhances participation from more remote areas. Its ability to combine physical and online program delivery increases its flexibility and resilience—important assets for Lab implementation.
4. Institutionally, Talent Match has a capable internal team of 5 professionals—including coordinators, trainers, and outreach officers—who bring technical expertise in employability, entrepreneurship, and youth leadership. The organization benefits from a network of industry mentors and donor partners, ensuring consistent quality, access to professional role models, and exposure to real-world opportunities for participants.
5. Financially, while the organization’s annual budget remains modest, it has demonstrated reliability in managing donor funds and delivering tangible outcomes. With targeted support from Expertise France in areas such as strategic financial planning, data management (M&E), EU reporting methods Talent Match could further enhance sustainability and program impact. Conclusion: Talent Match is well-positioned to implement the New Leaders Lab, particularly for modules focused on employability, entrepreneurship, and leadership development. Its strong operational base, relevant thematic expertise, and inclusive programming make it an ideal partner for piloting and scaling Lab activities aimed at empowering young Rwandans to become competent, resilient, and socially responsible leaders. Regarding the capacity to manage the budget, Talent Match could eventually partner with another organization such as Idebate or Resonate and benefit from their experience and human capital.
Musanze Hanga Hub demonstrates promising:
Musanze Hanga Hub demonstrates promising potential and growing institutional capacity to implement the New Leaders Lab, particularly for youth entrepreneurship, innovation, and leadership development in rural and underserved regions. Established in 2022 and registered as an NGO in Rwanda, the Hub operates with an annual budget of approximately €30,000. Its mixed funding model—combining donor support and local partnerships—enables it to maintain relevant programming while deepening its community-based approach.
1. The Hub offers a dedicated co-working and training space equipped with computers and learning materials, allowing young entrepreneurs to access practical tools for project development. Youth engagement is notably strong, with participants actively contributing to project design, workshops, mentorship, and peer-learning activities. These participatory methods align closely with the New Leaders Lab’s goals of fostering youth agency, ownership, and collaborative learning.
2. Musanze Hanga Hub plays a significant role in economic inclusion, especially for rural youth, low-income entrepreneurs, and school dropouts. Its focus on start-up support and entrepreneurship training responds directly to the employment challenges faced by young people in the Northern Province. Gender inclusion is moderate but improving: while male participation remains dominant, the Hub supports young women entrepreneurs and could achieve gender parity with targeted outreach efforts. inclusion Although measures for youth with disabilities are still limited, the organization provides safe, non-discriminatory learning environments and is well positioned to strengthen accessibility with external technical support.
3. The organization benefits from a geographically strategic location, offering accessible programs in a rural district outside major urban centers. This decentralization advantage makes Musanze Hanga Hub an important actor for expanding the Lab beyond Kigali and reaching youth who traditionally have fewer opportunities for leadership development. 
4. Programmatically, the Hub has built considerable experience in entrepreneurship training, start-up incubation, and leadership development. Its services—practical mentoring, technical workshops, workspace support, and guidance from local business mentors—are directly aligned with the competencies that the New Leaders Lab aims to enhance. The Hub effectively mobilizes trainers, entrepreneurs, and sector specialists, demonstrating strong potential for high-quality program delivery.
5. Institutionally, Musanze Hanga Hub is supported by a capable internal team of coordinators who ensure efficient program management. The organization’s interventions have shown meaningful social impact in rural communities and reflect solid pedagogical skills in developing training modules, incubator content, and youth leadership activities. The Hub also maintains active partnerships with foundations and government agencies, illustrating its credibility and ability to manage donor-funded initiatives. Conclusion: Musanze Hanga Hub is a promising and capable structure for implementing the New Leaders Lab. Its combination of practical entrepreneurship support, community-based operations, and growing institutional capacity makes it a valuable potential partner for the New Leaders Lab in Rwanda. Although the hub was founded through public support, its day-to-day operations are not financed by the government, which could justify an exception under the New Leaders Lab framework. Ensuring clear operational and financial independence and maintaining transparency in governance would be key to preserving eligibility and reinforcing credibility.
Resonate demonstrates a high level of in:
Resonate demonstrates a high level of institutional capacity and thematic relevance to implement the New Leaders Lab, particularly in the fields of women’s empowerment, youth confidence-building, and leadership development. Founded in 2013 by experienced women leaders, Resonate operates as a social enterprise registered in Rwanda and the USA, with an annual budget of approximately €500,000—well above the threshold required for Lab implementation. The organization reaches over 50,000 young women annually through programs delivered in equipped training spaces in Kigali and partner community centers. Participant and partners feedback consistently highlights strong satisfaction and active co-creation in workshops, storytelling sessions, and leadership activities.
1. Resonate’s programming is deeply rooted in storytelling, confidence-building, and personal empowerment, offering young women the tools to express themselves, advocate for their needs, and take initiative. These approaches align closely with the New Leaders Lab’s emphasis on leadership development, psychosocial strengthening, and youth agency. Over the last 48 months, the organization has consistently delivered high-quality leadership programs tailored to women from low-income backgrounds, rural areas, and marginalized communities—demonstrating both relevance and adaptability.
2. Gender inclusion is a major strength: women represent nearly 80% of participants, and female leadership is embedded throughout the organization’s governance and staffing. While the primary focus remains on women, Resonate’s safe, inclusive, and non-discriminatory learning environments offer strong foundations for expanding toward mixed-gender cohorts if required by the Lab. Accessibility for youth with disabilities remains limited, but the organization shows attentiveness to inclusion and is open to strengthening these mechanisms.
3. Resonate maintains regional diversity, operating not only in Kigali but also in rural and low-income districts, ensuring that marginalized youth can participate in leadership activities. Hybrid program delivery—combining physical workshops with virtual formats—expands outreach and strengthens the organization’s flexibility and resilience.
4. Institutionally, Resonate has a strong internal operational team of 12 people composed of coordinators, trainers, and outreach officers, capable of delivering complex leadership and empowerment programs at scale. The organization mobilizes experienced facilitators, coaches, storytellers, and guest speakers, ensuring high pedagogical quality. Its leadership, storytelling, and advocacy models align closely with the Lab’s core objectives and can enrich Lab content on communication, agency, and civic engagement.
5. Financially, Resonate has maintained consistent partnerships with donor agencies and international organizations since its founding. This experience demonstrates its capacity to manage significant grants, comply with reporting standards, and ensure accountability—key requirements for implementing a program such as the New Leaders Lab. Conclusion: Resonate is highly suited to implement the New Leaders Lab, particularly for components related to leadership development, personal empowerment, storytelling, and engagement of marginalized young women. Its strong institutional capacity, experienced team, and well-established pedagogical approach make it a credible lead or co-implementing partner. With targeted support to strengthen disability inclusion measures, Resonate is well positioned to contribute meaningfully to a program such as the NEW LEADERS LAB aimed at cultivating confident, empowered, and socially engaged young leaders across Rwanda.
iDebate Rwanda demonstrates strong insti:
iDebate Rwanda demonstrates strong institutional maturity and operational readiness to implement the New Leaders Lab. Established in 2012 and officially registered as an NGO, the organization manages an annual budget of approximately €160,000 and engages over 50,000 youth through its nationwide debate and civic leadership programs. Its long-standing experience, structured governance, and broad partnerships with schools and educators provide a solid platform for scaling leadership and civic engagement initiatives.
1. With over a decade of experience, iDebate Rwanda has developed a well-established methodology combining debate education, mentorship, and civic participation. The organization designs and delivers structured curricula in critical thinking, public speaking, and leadership—core competencies that align directly with the objectives of the New Leaders Lab. Youth participation is active and participatory: beneficiaries frequently contribute to program design, facilitation, and peer mentoring, which illustrates a strong culture of ownership and learning-by-doing.
2. The organization demonstrates commendable gender inclusion, with women representing around 70% of debate program participants, 52% of volunteers, and 40% of leadership roles. This balanced representation reflects a healthy and inclusive leadership pipeline. iDebate Rwanda also prioritizes diversity and accessibility, engaging students from underserved schools, low-income communities, and rural areas. Although most activities are conducted in urban centers, deliberate outreach ensures regional participation and inclusion of marginalized groups.
3. Its inclusive philosophy is reflected in ongoing collaborations to improve accessibility for youth with disabilities, including partnerships with organizations serving young people with visual, hearing, or speech impairments. This openness to partnership and adaptation shows readiness to integrate inclusive and equitable approaches, which are central to the New Leaders Lab’s methodology.
4. Institutionally, iDebate Rwanda benefits from a professional operational structure of 15 people including program coordinators, trainers, and outreach staff, ensuring efficient program management and delivery. The team’s academic and civic background reinforces its credibility and pedagogical expertise. By combining education, mentorship, and civic action, the organization nurtures youth who are confident, articulate, and socially responsible — all key outcomes the New Leaders Lab aims to promote.
5. Financially, the organization maintains a diversified donor base and programmatic partnerships, which provides relative stability. It also demonstrates capacity to handle grants and deliver accountable results. nevertheless, continued support from Expertise France in impact measurement, EU standard, long-term funding diversification would strengthen institutional resilience and enhance program scalability. Conclusion: Given its structured programs, experienced staff, gender-balanced leadership, and pedagogical excellence in civic education, iDebate Rwanda is highly capable of implementing the New Leaders Lab. The organization’s proven record in debate, youth leadership, and inclusive engagement aligns perfectly with the Lab’s vision to cultivate a new generation of ethical, critical-thinking leaders in Rwanda.

Our Past Initiative demonstrates a stron:
Our Past Initiative demonstrates a strong foundation for implementing the New Leaders Lab, thanks to its established experience in peacebuilding, storytelling, and youth reconciliation. Founded by young leaders committed to nation building, the organization has been operational since 2012 and is officially registered as an NGO in Rwanda. With an annual reach of over 20,000 young people—many from vulnerable backgrounds affected by conflict, trauma, or displacement—Our Past Initiative has proven its ability to mobilize large groups and sustain community-based programs across multiple districts.
1. Its methodology, rooted in storytelling, remembrance, and psychosocial empowerment, aligns closely with the Lab’s objectives of nurturing civic-minded and empathetic leadership. Through community workshops, cultural activities, and mentorship programs, the organization provides safe and inclusive spaces for dialogue, healing, and civic engagement. These approaches naturally foster the leadership, communication, and social responsibility skills that the New Leaders Lab seeks to strengthen.
2. Gender inclusion is a visible strength, with women representing around 50% of participants in reconciliation and storytelling activities. Programs are accessible and community-based, reaching rural and low-income youth, and actively integrating cultural diversity and gender sensitivity. Although accessibility for youth with disabilities remains limited, the organization’s commitment to inclusion and safe participation demonstrates readiness to integrate more inclusive strategies with the Lab’s support
3. Over the past four years, Our Past Initiative has developed and delivered original content that combines leadership training with reconciliation and psychosocial support, working with local facilitators and conflict-resolution experts. This experience reflects strong pedagogical capacity and a solid understanding of participatory training methodologies, both essential for leading Lab sessions. 
4. Institutionally, the organization operates with a moderate but experienced coordination team of 6 people supported by local partners and facilitators. Its mission—to rebuild unity, promote healing, and empower youth through cultural and social engagement—perfectly complements the New Leaders Lab’s vision of developing new generations of ethical and community-driven leaders.
5. While the organization’s financial base remains modest (around €50,000 annually, primarily from grants) this weakness can be effectively addressed through targeted technical assistance from Expertise France / the New Leaders Lab project. Strengthening M&E systems, and resource mobilization strategies would enhance its long-term sustainability and operational efficiency. Conclusion: Given its deep community engagement, experience in psychosocial and leadership programming, inclusive approach, and pedagogical strength, Our Past Initiative is well positioned to implement the New Leaders Lab. With tailored capacity-building support in M&E System and financial management, it can effectively deliver a high-impact program that empowers young leaders across Rwanda. For the first phase, Our Past Initiative can co-deliver NLL with a more mature NGO (RWW or iDebate) to manage administrative load while leveraging their strong thematic strengths.

1. Infrastructures et moyens matériels\n:
1. Infrastructure and material resources
 Premises often insufficient, dilapidated or poorly adapted.
 
 Lack of equipment (furniture, computer equipment, internet connection, library, sports/cultural equipment).
 
 Accessibility difficulties (space too far away or poorly located).
 2. Financial resources and sustainability
 
 Low funding to ensure activities on a regular basis.
 Excessive dependence on external aid or one-off projects.
 Lack of sustainability plan and revenue generation mechanisms.
 
  3. Supervision and governance
  Poorly trained or insufficient number of supervisors.
  Low involvement of young people in management and decision-making.
  Lack of clear coordination between structures (NGO, State, partners).
 
  4. Youth participation and mobilization
  Low use of the space due to lack of attractive or suitable activities.
  Inequalities of access (girls, young people with disabilities, rural areas).
  Lack of communication and awareness among young people.
 
  5. Offer of activities and relevance
  Limited activities, not very diversified or not adapted to real needs (professional training, entrepreneurship, culture, sport).
  Lack of initiatives promoting innovation, leadership and creativity of young people.
  Weak link between the youth space and local opportunities (employment, internships, partnerships).
 
  6. Socio-economic environment
  Context marked by unemployment, poverty and sometimes insecurity.
  Challenges linked to school dropout, early pregnancies, drug addiction, etc. Insufficiency of concrete public policies to support youth.

L’un des principaux défis auxquels nous:
One of the main challenges we face is the lack of material and financial resources to meet the growing demand of young people for professional training. Many young people, particularly those from vulnerable backgrounds or displaced by conflicts, show a strong interest in learning trades such as cutting and sewing, computing, or craft manufacturing, but reception capacities remain limited.
 We also face a lack of suitable equipment (machines, tools, stable Internet connections) and dedicated spaces for practical training. This constraint affects the quality of learning and limits the long-term impact.
 Another major challenge is reduced access to post-training support, particularly in terms of professional integration, entrepreneurial monitoring, or microfinancing of the initiatives of young people trained.
 Finally, poor access to regional or international networking opportunities deprives young people of an opening to other models of success, collaboration or mentoring.
 Despite these challenges, our commitment remains firm to offer young people concrete alternatives to idleness, forced migration or delinquency, through training, empowerment and local innovation.

Le centre AKA insuffisances et défis:\n:
The AKA center shortcomings and challenges:
 
 Structural and financial challenges
 
 - Lack of sustainable financing: 
 The AKA center operates without state support or regular patronage, which makes their sustainability fragile.
 - Limited access to infrastructure: Spaces often lack technical equipment (sound, light, security) or suitable places for exhibitions and performances.
 
 Artistic and community challenges
 
 - Visibility of local artists: It is difficult to bring out talent in a landscape dominated by larger institutions or external influences.
 - Intergenerational dialogue: Creating bridges between young artists and elders requires attentive mediation and adapted formats.
 - Cultural resistance: Certain audiences may be reluctant to contemporary or engaged artistic forms, especially if they disrupt social norms.

Insuffisances et Défis de notre ASBL\n \:
Shortcomings and Challenges of our non-profit organization
 
 1. Lack of funding
 
 We face recurring financial difficulties to improve our working conditions.
 
 Several promising projects remain unfinished due to lack of sufficient resources.
 
 
 
 2. Absence of regular landlords
 
 Despite the relevance and social impact of our projects, we encounter obstacles in attracting and retaining donors.
 
 This lack of constant support slows down the implementation of our initiatives.
 
 
 
 3. Blocked project: Reception and reintegration center
 
 We designed a project to build a reception, listening and reintegration center for orphaned children from the M23 war.
 
 This project remains limited and unrealized due to lack of adequate financial resources.
 
 
 
 4. Multiple social and logistical challenges
 
 The needs on the ground are immense and varied, which places additional pressure on our limited capacities.
 
 Material and organizational constraints complicate the achievement of our missions.

1. MUSHAGALUSA MUNIKE MOÏSE FREED: \n \n:
1. MUSHAGALUSA MUNIKE MOSES FREED: 
 
 Trained in law, accomplished musician artist with more than 7 years of experience in musical composition, arrangement, animation of artistic meetings, artistic direction and stage performance, he was born in Bukavu, in the east of the DRC, on March 3, 2000. Passionate about the promotion of peace and living together through music, he has notably participated in certified projects such as MUSIC IN AFRICA LIVE 2022, the AKATUUTI series, the activities of JUA-ASBL, AMANI'S SHUJAA, Reproductive Health IPAS & Embassy of Sweden in Kinshasa, as well as CHOREOGRAPHIC MEETING OF THE GREAT LAKES.
 
 Public lawyer, entrepreneur and cultural administrator, with more than 5 years of experience in the management of structures (and their resources) as well as in organizational consulting, Freed has also brought his expertise on several occasions in the areas of contracts and the development of public policies. He notably founded and manages IMA PRODUCTIONS, a music production and entertainment company based in Bukavu, and was legal advisor to DanceBeatRecords.
 
 An experienced consultant in the development and implementation of communications and awareness programs, as well as in the creation and management of regional partnerships, Freed notably serves as a program and communications consultant at BUKAVU SLAM SESSION, and as a consultant in regional partnerships, while also being a musician at East African Records.
 
 2. AKONKWA BUJIRIRI OSÉE ELEKTRA
 
 Osée Elektra, whose real name is Akonkwa Bujiriri Osée, is a multidisciplinary artist, poet, slammer, rapper and cultural entrepreneur from Goma, in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo. He is the creator of Slam Elektrik, a unique style that combines slam, rap and traditional African rhythms to transmit powerful, committed messages deeply rooted in the social and cultural realities of his country.
 
 Committed to promoting peace, living together and collective memory, Osée Elektra places art at the service of social transformation. As co-founder and artistic director of JUA – ASBL, he coordinates regional projects in the African Great Lakes region, aimed at strengthening the empowerment of artists, structuring cultural and creative industries, and combating hate speech through art.
 
 Recognized as one of the major voices of slam in Central Africa, he received the Kema Awards 2022 for his cultural and social impact. He has also participated in numerous artistic festivals nationally and internationally (Senegal, Burundi, Uganda, Comoros, DRC, Tanzania, etc...).

 🎨 Identity and origins

 🖌️ Artistic journey

  - Use of bright colors, archaeological textures, hieroglyphs, mathematical signs

The founders of Wokovu Way are young, committed humanitarian and social leaders from the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, a region marked by conflicts and recurring humanitarian crises.

Stiven GANDZIAMI is a young entrepreneur and civil society activist, holder of a BAC+4 in Engineering Sciences from the UNESCO Chair, mention Electrical and Electronic Engineering, electronics specialty, and a License in Electrical Engineering, electronics and telecommunications specialty, obtained at the École Nationale Supérieure Polytechnique (ENSP) of Marien Ngouabi University. Profil de la fondatrice – Mme Yessei Oss:
Profile of the founder – Ms. Yessei Ossebi Zoabi

Aged 36, Ms. Yessei Ossebi Zoabi is a Congolese entrepreneur, architect designer and mother of two children. She is the General Director of the YODAGROUP architectural firm, recognized in the sub-region for more than a decade for its prestigious achievements (BGFI BANK agencies in Congo and the DRC, ECOBANK Congo headquarters, Cofina Congo headquarters, hotels, restaurants and residences).

A visionary, she founded Jeunesse & Perspectives in order to put her expertise and experience at the service of Congolese youth. Convinced that “there is no point in shining alone when so much remains to be accomplished”, she works to create a space for learning, sharing and opportunities.

Ms. Ossebi Zoabi is also the founder of the association FEM – Femme en Mouvement, through which she has led concrete social actions, such as the rehabilitation of the neonatology department of the Military Hospital of Brazzaville.

Key skills:

Leadership and management of large-scale projects.

Expertise in architecture, interior design and construction.

Proven experience in entrepreneurship, support and mentoring.

Mobilization of institutional and private partners.

Social and associative commitment in favor of women and young people.

Through her journey, Ms. Yessei Ossebi Zoabi embodies the vision of Jeunesse & Perspectives: to train, inspire and connect Congolese youth to build a more inclusive and innovative future.
